title: 109_hr5349
content: The Nurse Loan Forgiveness Act of 2006 may be cited as the ``Nurse Loan Forgiveness Act of 2006''. The Congress finds a significant shortage of nurses in the United States healthcare system, with 118,000 nurses needed to fill vacancies at hospitals. By 2020, there will be a shortage of over 400,000 registered nurses nationwide. Despite the high demand for healthcare services, there is a 28 percent decrease in national licensure examination for entry-level registered nurses. The Department of Labor projects a 29 percent increase in the need for nurses nationwide from 2004 to 2014, with a 13 percent increase for all other occupations. The General Accounting Office estimates that 40 percent of all registered nurses will be older than age 50 by the year 2010, and an estimated 16 percent of registered nurses in 2004 have chosen not to practice in the field. A new section, SEC. 428L, is added to the Higher Education Act of 1965, establishing a loan forgiveness program for nurses. The new section, SEC. 428L, of the Higher Education Act of 1965 establishes a loan forgiveness program for nurses to encourage individuals to enter and continue in the nursing profession and reward them for their service by reducing student debt. The Secretary is authorized to forgive student loan debt for eligible borrowers who serve for the first 5 complete years after the enactment of this section. The Secretary is authorized to provide loan forgiveness to eligible borrowers who assume repayment obligations or cancel loan amounts under specific loan programs. Loan consolidation is limited to certain types of loans for eligibility. Loan forgiveness is available to registered nurses who have worked for at least one year in an approved healthcare facility and are not in default on their loans. The forgiveness amounts range from $2,000 to $3,000 based on the number of years of employment. Loan forgiveness under this section is based on the number of years of employment, ranging from $2,000 to $5,000. Eligible borrowers must submit a complete application to the Secretary for forgiveness. Loan forgiveness is granted on a first-come, first-served basis, and regulations may be prescribed as necessary. No repayment of loans will be refunded under this section. Authorization is given for loan repayment refunds. Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this section and another section of the National and Community Service Act. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2007 and the following 5 years.
